newsitem.title: UK: Steelmakers may face oversupply in 2001 - study.
newsitem.headline: Steelmakers may face oversupply in 2001 - study.

text.p: The world's steelmakers may face a risk of oversupply at the beginning of the next decade, steel industry consultancy MEPS (Europe) Ltd said on Wednesday.
The firm predicted global steel productive capacity would rise by about 80 million tonnes in 2001 from last year's total of 780 million, while demand was expected to grow by only 70 million tonnes.
"Oversupply at the start of the next decade is a distinctive possibility. Substantial steelmaking capacity was approved in 1996 for installation before 2001," MEPS said in a study.
World crude steel production was forecast to grow to 820 million tonnes in 2001, about 70 million tonnes above the level in 1996, the firm said.
Finished steel consumption was seen growing by 70 million tonnes between 1996 and 2001 from last year's level of 650 million tonnes.
The firm said molten iron production was expected to increase by 35 million tonnes over the period to about 554 million in 2001.
